title: PHPprev()Function

metadata.description: Learn about PHPprev()Function with clear explanations and practical examples.

content_sections.title: Details
content_sections.content:
Example Output the value of the current, "; echo echo prev($people); ?> Definition and Usage The prev() function moves the internal pointer to, and outputs, the Related methods: - moves the internal pointer to, and outputs, the current() - returns the value of the current element in an array end() - moves the internal pointer to, and outputs, the last element in the array reset() - moves the internal pointer to the first element of the array each() - returns the current element key and value, and moves the internal pointer forward Syntax prev( array ) Parameter Values Parameter Description array Required. Specifies the array to use Technical Details Return Value: Returns the value of the PHP Version: 4+ More Examples Example A demonstration of all related methods: "; // The current element is Peter echo echo current($people) . "
"; // Now the current element is Joe echo prev($people) . "
"; // The echo end($people) . "
"; // The last element is Cleveland echo prev($people) . "
"; // The echo current($people) . "
"; // Now the current element is Glenn echo reset($people) . "
"; // Moves the internal pointer to the first element of the array, which is Peter echo print_r (each($people)); // Returns the key and value of the current element (now Joe), and moves the internal pointer forward ?> ★ +1

content_sections.title: Example
content_sections.code:
"; echo next($people) . "
"; echo prev($people); ?>

content_sections.title: Example
content_sections.code:
"; // The current element is Peter echo next($people) . "
"; // The next element of Peter is Joe echo current($people) . "
"; // Now the current element is Joe echo prev($people) . "
"; // The previous element of Joe is Peter echo end($people) . "
"; // The last element is Cleveland echo prev($people) . "
"; // The previous element of Cleveland is Glenn echo current($people) . "
"; // Now the current element is Glenn echo reset($people) . "
"; // Moves the internal pointer to the first element of the array, which is Peter echo next($people) . "
"; // The next element of Peter is Joe print_r (each($people)); // Returns the key and value of the current element (now Joe), and moves the internal pointer forward ?>

practice_exercises.solution:
"; // The current element is Peter echo next($people) . "
"; // The next element of Peter is Joe echo current($people) . "
"; // Now the current element is Joe echo prev($people) . "
"; // The previous element of Joe is Peter echo end($people) . "
"; // The last element is Cleveland echo prev($people) . "
"; // The previous element of Cleveland is Glenn echo current($people) . "
"; // Now the current element is Glenn echo reset($people) . "
"; // Moves the internal pointer to the first element of the array, which is Peter echo next($people) . "
"; // The next element of Peter is Joe print_r (each($people)); // Returns the key and value of the current element (now Joe), and moves the internal pointer forward ?>

summary: This tutorial covers PHPprev()Function concepts and techniques. You'll learn how to use PHPprev()Function effectively, including key principles, common patterns, and practical examples. By the end of this tutorial, you'll have a solid understanding of PHPprev()Function and how to apply it in your projects.
